title: X was Down (again)
html:
X experienced yet another significant outage lasting over an hour. During this time, users were unable to refresh their timelines on mobile apps, and the web version displayed a generic welcome message. Netblocks confirmed the outage as significant and international, not related to country-level blocks. While timelines were inaccessible, users could still post, and notifications for new posts were functioning. The outage also affected the visibility of accounts like Elon Musk's and current CEO Linda Yaccarino. The problem began just before 12:30 AM ET, with no immediate indication of the cause. Service was restored around 1:35 AM ET, but the cause of the problem remains unexplained.

Source: The Verge

title: X outage broke all outgoing links (again)
html:
X experienced an outage where all outgoing links stopped functioning, redirecting users to an error page with a quirky message. This issue, which lasted for about an hour, is reminiscent of a similar incident in March when links and images were taken down due to an internal change gone wrong. The March outage was attributed to a mistake by the site's sole remaining site reliability engineer following massive layoffs.

The recent outage was resolved without any public acknowledgment from X's support team or executives.

Source: The Verge

title: Elon Musk tells advertisers to "Go fuck yourself"
html:
At the DealBook Summit in New York, Elon Musk expressed strong disdain for advertisers boycotting the platform due to his amplification of antisemitic posts. He accused the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) of trying to "kill X" by urging advertisers to avoid the site and responded to perceived blackmail attempts over advertising with a blunt "Go fâ€” yourself." Musk singled out Disney CEO Bob Iger during his remarks and suggested that his fans might boycott advertisers in retaliation. Despite recent apologies for his controversial posts, Musk's actions have led to a significant pullback from major advertisers like Disney, Apple, and others, and have driven some high-profile users away from the platform.

Source: CNBC

title: X sues Media Matters for America
html:
Elon Musk's X Corp. has sued Media Matters for America, alleging defamation after the nonprofit reported that ads on X were shown next to pro-Nazi content, causing advertisers to pull out. The lawsuit claims Media Matters used deceptive tactics to make such ad pairings appear more common than they were. X CEO Linda Yaccarino defended the platform, asserting that these pairings were not widely seen by users. In response, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has launched an investigation into Media Matters. Media Matters stands by its reporting, calling the lawsuit an attempt to silence criticism. The issue is part of broader concerns about brand safety and Musk's recent controversial statements.

Source: Axios

title: Disney, Apple, IBM and more Companies pulling ads from X
html:
Several major advertisers are withdrawing from X, significantly impacting its ad business. This follows Elon Musk's endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory and reports of increased antisemitism and hate speech on the platform. Media Matters for America highlighted that ads from various companies appeared alongside far-right posts on X. Despite X CEO Linda Yaccarino's statements about combating antisemitism and discrimination, companies like Apple, IBM, Disney, Comcast/NBCUniversal, Lions Gate Entertainment, Warner Bros. Discovery, and Paramount have paused their ads. Additionally, the European Commission has frozen advertising on X due to a rise in disinformation and hate speech.

The White House has also condemned Musk's post promoting antisemitic and racist hate.

Source: Axios

title: X Disabled feature for reporting electoral misinformation
html:
X has disabled a feature allowing users to report electoral misinformation, according to a report by research organization Reset.Tech Australia. This change comes ahead of significant elections in the US and a major referendum in Australia. Initially introduced in 2022, the feature allowed users to report misleading political posts, but recently, the "politics" category was removed from the reporting options in all regions except the European Union. While users can still report posts for other issues like promoting violence or hate speech, the removal of the political misinformation reporting feature may hinder efforts to curb electoral falsehoods on the platform.

Despite the criticism, Musk advocates for X's "Community Notes" feature as a better alternative for fact-checking.

Source: Reuters

title: X announces shutdown of Circles
html:
X has announced that it will be shutting down the Circles feature, which allows users to share posts with a select group of people rather than all followers, by October 31st. Introduced in August 2022, Circles aimed to provide a more private sharing experience. However, some posts intended for Circles were mistakenly appearing on the platform's For You timeline, compromising the feature's privacy. While X did not provide a specific reason for discontinuing Circles, the platform has been focusing more on its Communities feature, which is similar to Facebook Groups. This shift might be part of the reason for deeming Circles redundant. Users will no longer be able to create new posts for their Circle or add people to it after the shutdown date, but they will still be able to remove people from their existing Circles.

Source: The Verge

title: X updates its terms to ban crawling and scraping
html:
X has updated its terms of service to explicitly ban web scraping and crawling without prior written consent. This move is likely aimed at preventing AI models from training on its data. The previous terms allowed crawling in line with the platform's robots.txt file, but the new terms remove this provision. Additionally, X has modified its robots.txt file to disallow crawlers from accessing specific types of information like likes and retweets. The changes come after Musk has expressed opposition to companies using Twitter/X data to train AI models, even going as far as filing lawsuits against unknown entities for scraping data.

Source: TechCrunch

title: Elon Musk implies X could only be worth $4 billion now
html:
Elon Musk, in a post attacking the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) for allegedly causing a significant loss in revenue for X, claimed that the platform has lost 90% of its value since his acquisition, potentially bringing its worth down to $4 billion. Musk's attack came after ADL objected to anti-Semitic tweets from far-right groups on X. Musk accused ADL of being overly aggressive in demanding account bans and blamed them for a substantial part of X's revenue loss. He stated that ADL might be responsible for around $4 billion of value destruction, implying a total loss of $40 billion from the original $44 billion purchase price.

Source: Fortune

title: Elon Musk Booed at a Video Game Tournament
html:
Following the rebrand to X, Elon Musk faced public backlash during his appearance at the Valorant World Championship Final in Los Angeles. As he was briefly shown on camera with his son X Ã† A-12, the crowd booed him and chanted "Bring back Twitter!"

Source: PC Mag

title: It took 2 days to remove the account of the man suspected of California Pride-flag killing of Laura Carleton
html:
It took two days to delete the account of the man suspected of killing Laura Ann Carleton because she displayed a Pride flag outside her California clothing store. The suspect used X to share homophobic and antisemitic views, with a pinned tweet showing a burning Pride flag. Despite attempts by users to report the account, X initially responded saying the account hadn't violated safety policies. The account was eventually suspended on August 24, 2023, following the killing on August 18. The incident highlights a rise in hate speech on X, possibly exacerbated by mass layoffs and Elon Musk's "free speech absolutism" stance since taking over the platform in 2022.

The European Commission has also reported the platform has responded slower to reports, with hate speech, particularly against women, Jewish people, and the LGBTQ+ community, noticeably higher.

Source: Insider

title: X blocked links to a Democratic political tool for a week
html:
The social media platform temporarily blocked links to EveryActionâ€™s NGP VAN, a widely used political organizing software for Democratic and progressive campaigns. For a week, users were unable to share links related to volunteer events, donation portals, and other resources for left-leaning political causes. Users attempting to post such links encountered an error message labeling the content as "potentially harmful." Although the issue has been resolved, X has not provided an explanation for the block.

Source: TechCrunch

title: A Glitch wipes out most pictures and links tweeted before December 2014
html:
X started experiencing issues displaying old tweets with images or links shortened by Twitter's URL shortener, particularly affecting posts prior to December 2014. Notably, a famous 2014 Oscars selfie tweet by Ellen DeGeneres was impacted, though the image has since been restored. Speculations arose regarding the glitch's cause, but evidence suggests it's likely an error rather than an intentional move.

Source: The Verge

title: Elon Musk Says X (Twitter) Will No Longer Let You Block Other Users
html:
Elon Musk announced that users will no longer have the ability to block other accounts on the platform. Musk stated that the block feature "makes no sense" and will be removed, except for direct messages. Instead, he suggests users utilize the mute function (The mute feature currently allows users to hide posts from specific accounts without unfollowing or blocking them).

It remains uncertain when this change will actually be implemented and if it would violate the terms of service of Apple and Google app stores, as both require apps to provide the ability to block users.

Source: The Washington post

title: Elon Musk steals @x and  @xAI from its original users
html:
Elon Musk's rebranding of Twitter to X involved not only changing the official @Twitter handle to @x but also taking over the @xai handle for his new AI company, xAI. Both handles were already registered by active users, who were not offered any form of financial compensation or negotiation. The original owner of the @x handle was offered some merchandise and a meeting with the X team after the fact, while the Japanese user who originally had the @xai handle was not even notified by email.

Source: Mashable

title: Twitter Rebrands to X
html: Over the weekend, Twitter underwent a significant rebranding, changing its iconic blue bird logo to a simple black 'X'. Elon Musk made the unexpected announcement, sharing images of Twitter's headquarters illuminated with the new 'X' logo. Despite the rebranding to "X", some elements of Twitter remain, such as posts still being referred to as tweets and the retention of notable blue branding.

title: NPR Goes dark on Twitter
html:
NPR has decided to cease its activity on Twitter after being labeled as "State-Affiliated Media" by the platform.

Source: Gizmodo

title: Twitter down for two hours around the world
html:
Twitter experienced a two-hour global outage that affected its "Following" and "For You" feeds. The issue was reported by the outage-tracking site DownDetector and seemed to be resolved within two hours. Despite the outage, users were still able to tweet, although their tweets were not visible in the affected feeds.

The outage occurred shortly after Twitter reportedly laid off 10% of its current 2,000-strong workforce. Experts have warned that such major job cuts could lead to technical issues, and Twitter's reliability has reportedly decreased since Elon Musk took over as CEO.

Source: BBC

title: Twitter lays off at least 200 more employees
html:
This reduction represents about 10% of the company's remaining 2,000 employees. In the days leading up to the layoffs, Twitter's internal communication tool, Slack, was disabled, hindering employee interactions and access to company data. Some employees realized they were part of the layoffs when they found themselves locked out of their corporate email accounts and laptops on Saturday night.

Source: NY Times

title: Elon fires top engineer over declining view counts
html:
Elon Musk, concerned about the declining visibility of his tweets, convened a meeting with Twitter engineers and advisors to understand the drop in his engagement numbers. Despite having over 100 million followers, Musk's tweets were only garnering tens of thousands of impressions. When one of the company's principal engineers suggested that public interest in Musk's activities might be diminishing, Musk responded by firing them.

Internal data showed that Musk's popularity peaked in April 2022, but has since declined. With the introduction of public view counts for tweets, the platform has seen a decrease in user engagement, with U.S. Twitter usage dropping nearly 9% post-Musk's takeover. Current Twitter employees describe the workplace as chaotic, with Musk's unpredictable management style causing confusion and stress. The company's compliance with FTC regulations is also in question, raising concerns about potential fines and regulatory scrutiny.

Source: Platformer

title: Twitter users see error messages they are "over daily tweet limit"
html:
Twitter users experienced a brief outage that prevented them from tweeting, with some receiving a message stating they had exceeded the daily tweet limit, even if they hadn't posted that day. The outage was reported by DownDetector. The outage was partially resolved, but users also reported issues with TweetDeck, a dashboard used with Twitter.

Source: BBC

title: Twitter Fires 40 Data Scientists
html:
40 data scientists and engineers working on advertising were let go following the third round of layoffs since Musk took over. The layoffs targeted areas that Twitterâ€™s leadership considers to be failing and unimportant, such as the ads products and data science areas, a source said.

Source: The Information

title: Facing eviction, Twitter closes Seattle office
html:
Twitter is reportedly closing its Seattle office and facing eviction due to unpaid rent as part of cost-cutting measures under Elon Musk. The Seattle office, which was Twitter's second-largest engineering hub before Musk's acquisition, had already seen layoffs of 208 employees earlier this year.

The New York Times notes that Musk has reduced nearly 75% of Twitter's workforce since taking over and is also shutting down data centers and terminating janitorial services to further cut costs.

Source: GeekWire

title: Twitter rolls out its paid subscription service, hilarity follows
html: Twitter introduces a revamped subscription service, Twitter Blue, priced at $8 monthly, offering users access to account verification. Previously, Twitter verified notable individuals like celebrities and politicians to deter impersonation. Elon Musk warns of strict actions against impersonators, with exceptions for parody accounts. However, a day later, the platform sees a surge in fake accounts mimicking public figures and brands, such as LeBron James, Rudy Giuliani, Nintendo of America, and Musk's Tesla. This leads Twitter to reintroduce a secondary "official" tag system causing even more confusion.

title: Twitter fires nearly 50% of its staff
html: Twitter initiated layoffs that affect approximately half of its 7,500-person workforce, as communicated in an email to the affected employees. The email also stated that the affected employees' last working day was the day the email was sent. While Employees should continue to receive compensation and benefits until the first week of January 2023, they were immediately locked out of Twitter systems like email and Slack. The company had previously informed its employees about the impending layoffs, emphasizing the necessity of the action to ensure Twitter's "future success".

title: Elon Musk Completes $44 Billion Deal to Buy Twitter
html:
Elon Musk has finalized his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter Inc, swiftly making significant changes upon taking ownership. After the acquisition, Musk tweeted "The bird is freed," hinting at his vision for fewer content restrictions on the platform. Despite his stance on free speech, Musk has expressed intentions to prevent Twitter from becoming a divisive echo chamber and has goals to combat spam bots and make content algorithms public. Musk's takeover was marked by the firing of top Twitter executives, including CEO Parag Agrawal, CFO Ned Segal, and legal affairs and policy chief Vijaya Gadde. A noticeable increase in hate speech by anonymous users on the platform also becomes immediately apparent.

Twitter's stock price closed at $53.86 before it was delisted from the New York Stock Exchange.
